text:

text:

name: sfchronicle
text: The U.S. has vastly ramped up its coronavirus testing capability, conducting nearly 15 million tests in June. But as cases have surged, the demand for testing has soared, surpassing capacity and creating a new testing crisis, the New York Times reports. https://t.co/POtTwM0v1J https://t.co/Wtn1JAeEgj

name: sfchronicle
text: Swiss architects of de Young Museum selected to do S.F. hospital. The firm, Herzog & de Meuron, will take the lead role in what is envisioned as a nearly 1 million square facility at UCSF‚Äôs Parnassus campus, on slopes just south of Golden Gate Park.  https://t.co/obgZ4nbdz5 https://t.co/uDwvN4JF2F

name: sfchronicle
text: Crews Fire near Gilroy grows to 5,400 acres, evacuations remain in place. Fire officials have closed Ca√±ada Road from Highway 152 to Gilroy Hot Springs. Thirty structures remained under threat. No injuries were reported. https://t.co/mV9dxZ1OjG https://t.co/smxmYp4jub

text:

name: sfchronicle
text:

name: sfchronicle
text: A Maryland vaccine maker that has never brought a product to market, Novavax, has won a $1.6 billion federal contract to expedite development of 100 million doses of a coronavirus vaccine by the beginning of next year, the New York Times reports. https://t.co/cPSyk4mCh4 https://t.co/fnIj9r5XPy

name: sfchronicle
text: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro, who has sought to minimize the coronavirus as he urges the country back to work, has tested positive for COVID-19, he told reporters on Tuesday. https://t.co/Sn79k61Ehq https://t.co/v22NgXWQSB

name: sfchronicle
text: The personal protective gear that was in dangerously short supply early in the coronavirus crisis is running low again as the virus resumes its rapid spread, the Associated Press reports. A national nursing union is concerned that gear has to be reused. https://t.co/VlE6nI7Gv7 https://t.co/bGdtocfAgD

name: sfchronicle
text: State reverses course, approves Santa Clara County reopening plan. A county order issued on July 2, which should now take effect July 13, allows some activities to resume, including gatherings of up to 60 people outdoors and up to 20 people indoors. https://t.co/9CFGREXXvn https://t.co/vXfUDOmIyF

name: sfchronicle
text: The Monterey Bay Aquarium has indefinitely postponed its planned July 13 reopening, the aquarium announced on its website. After a surge in infections in Monterey County, Gov. Gavin Newsom last week added the county to the coronavirus watch list.  https://t.co/8fkKY1XMdR https://t.co/PMeNd0UFiU

name: sfchronicle
text: Bay Area doctor shot and killed over the weekend while off-roading with his 15-year-old son, who escaped the gunman by hiding in the remote Sierra County wilderness. https://t.co/I0YAV0Njt5

name: sfchronicle
text: The emergencies chief of the World Health Organization said Tuesday that the coronavirus continues to speed up globally, and a spike in deaths could soon follow the marked increase in numbers of confirmed cases over past several weeks.  https://t.co/WaVdqM6i3B https://t.co/xWNbIf1e5z

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @SportingGreenSF: A‚Äôs pitcher Mike Fiers is cleared to practice but Jes√∫s Luzardo is still sidelined. https://t.co/lRV3u1CMFd https://t.co/mIpYiHHJ70

name: sfchronicle
text: Scientists have long contended that the coronavirus can linger in the air. Now 239 researchers in 32 countries are urging the World Health Organization to acknowledge the threat aerosols play in the transmission of the virus, especially indoors. https://t.co/beXOFPiTpT

name: sfchronicle
text: New cases of the coronavirus across California jumped by 8,417 Tuesday ‚Äî a sum that included catch-up numbers from counties that did not report daily counts over the weekend. The number represented the most ever recorded on one day.   https://t.co/b7y8BtfLkW https://t.co/DQGJzgokpO

name: sfchronicle
text: San Francisco Mayor London Breed announced on Tuesday that the city would not allow for indoor restaurant dining next week as it had previously planned. https://t.co/ekYvDq5Y44

name: sfchronicle
text: Trail camps at Point Reyes National Seashore are re-opening with an array of new rules in an effort to keep campers safe. Here's what you need to know: https://t.co/ogKf08sSI0

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúIt's new friends, it's no judgment.‚Äù A Lake Merritt workout group has grown from 3 to 30 during the pandemic. And many say they will swear off gyms altogether. https://t.co/YDkuoo7gtA

name: sfchronicle
text:
Mama Papa Lithuania is permanently shutting its doors, but not because of the coronavirus. Owner Vaidas Sukys is running for a parliament seat in Lithuania. 

The Alameda restaurant will close July 31. https://t.co/0ofWMGtt0j

name: sfchronicle
text: BART has a 15-step plan to welcome back riders: hospital-grade disinfectant, running longer trains and offering personal hand straps for purchase that riders can wash for reuse. https://t.co/6YVQvxsYg2

name: sfchronicle
text: Santa Clara health officials confirmed Tuesday that businesses not listed as ‚Äúhigh-risk‚Äù can reopen with social distancing and mask requirements starting July 13, and outdoor dining can continue. https://t.co/Vcw9toiPgB

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @hknightsf: My latest: A feel-good read. After 111 consecutive sunset serenades to console his sheltering neighbors, the Pied Piper of the Castro calls it quits. But not before his nightly bagpiping created community among his neighbors that never existed before. https://t.co/JfXmxmZqF7

name: sfchronicle
text: A San Francisco federal judge says he‚Äôs inclined to reject Bayer‚Äôs $1.25 billion plan to resolve future Roundup lawsuits with a scientific panel that would determine whether the herbicide causes cancer. https://t.co/WigerumN6w

name: sfchronicle
text: As California moves to ban singing and chanting in places of worship for public health reasons, Bay Area congregations have already adapted by moving musical celebration outside or going online. But some object to the ban. https://t.co/IhUqMqtAQp

name: sfchronicle
text: Contra Costa County reported another 214 cases of the coronavirus on Tuesday, and Santa Clara County recorded an additional 70 cases. https://t.co/QOD43EcX2o

name: sfchronicle
text: A Carmel Valley restaurant has been flooded with praise and gifts following a viral video in which a server ordered a man to leave after he made racist remarks and cursed at a family celebrating a birthday on the Fourth of July. https://t.co/FJUxtzMfkr

name: sfchronicle
text: The state is closely monitoring 23 of California‚Äôs 58 counties, including Contra Costa, Marin and Solano in the Bay Area, because of their high rate of new infections, positive tests or increasing hospitalizations. https://t.co/tpXbeLcs4G
